title: Changing my mind about surrendering my investment property
question: I have filed chapter 13 last year and included my investment condo.The attorney suggested I just surrender it. I agreed but now 1 year later with no actions from the bank, I would prefer to short sale it. I have realtors i know that will get the listing and I do not expect any profits from this since I am upside down by 80K. My attorney says he must petition the court to now let that property out of the bankruptcy and I need a reason for the courts to approve this action.Other than possibility looking better on my credit report as a short sale than a surrender, I dont have a reason. He said the court would not take that as a reason and will not suggest one that might be approved. Tenant is living rent free for the past year and she may want to buy it. What reason should be on the petition.
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Bankruptcy petition,Bankruptcy documents,Chapter 13 bankruptcy,Credit,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Chapter 13 bankruptcy reorganization plan,Residential property,Real estate finances,Short sales,Real estate and bankruptcy,Real estate,Homeowners' association
answers:
Your attorney doesn't seem to have much of an imagination!

I would cite as the reason for the short sale that it would resolve the claim of the secured creditor and not cost the other creditors anything. What more reason do you need???

With all due respect, the bankruptcy filing is the 800-lb elephant on your credit report; the difference between a voluntary surrender or a short-sale is going to be rather minimal in light of the big picture.

However, there may be tax consequences to take into account. Canceled debts dis charged in bankruptcy are not subject to 1099c issues, but investment properties that are short-sold may create a taxable event that you would owe taxes on.

Perhaps you should consider getting the tenant to pony up and pay rent,m and if she doesn't, then evict her! Do not let the tenant create financial instability that threatens your successful completion of the Plan.

I hope this response was helpful.

I disagree, the only good reason I could see is to get the property out of your name quicker. The title change ends the responsibility for taxes, maintenance and HOA dues. Whether you surrender or short sale makes no difference on your credit report, because the debt is discharged in bankruptcy either way.
